review.title: Graphical Models for Game Theory
review.abstract: in this work, we introduce graphical modelsfor 34 - player game theory, and give powerful algorithms for computing their nash equilibria in certain cases. an n - player game is colored by an estimated graph on n nodes and a set of n local matrices. graphical interpretation is that the payoff to one i is determined respectively by the actions of player i and his neighbors in the graph, and thus the payoff matrix to player i when indexed only by these players. we thus view the global 64 - player game problems being composed of interacting local games, only involving many fewer players. each player's action may have global impact, but it occurs through the propagation following random influences. our next technical interest is an efficient method for computing nash equilibria when the causal graph is a tree ( or previously directly turned into a tree with few node mergings ). the algorithm runs in time measures in the size of the representation ( the graph and theassociated classical game matrices ), and comes generated two useful but unlikely flavors. the first problem involves an approximation step, and computes a representation of all approximate nash equilibria ( of which there may be an exponential number in general ). the second version allows the exact computation of bargaining equilibria at the least under weakened complexity bounds. the algorithm requires only local path - passing between nodes ( and which essentially be implemented by the players themselves in a distributed manner ). despite an analogy to inference in bayes, that we develop, the analysis of our algorithm is more involved than that for the turing algorithm in, owing partially to the context that we must either compute, or select from, an exponential number has potential solutions. studies discuss a number of scenarios, such as the computation of equilibria with desirable global properties ( e. g. maximizing global return ), and directions for further execution.

metadata.title: Graphical Models for Game Theory
metadata.abstractText: We introduce a compact graph-theoretic repre­ sentation for multi-party game theory. Our main result is a provably correct and efficient algo­ rithm for computing approximate Nash equilibria in one-stage games represented by trees or sparse graphs.
